--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:

> 
> Also of note is a simple techique I've been using for improving 
> performance with a large numbers of  tests per evaluation - If I 
want a 
> score out of 1000 tests then I initially just run the first 100 
tests, 
> if 100 is scroed then I go on a test against the next 100, and so 
on up 
> to 1000. Thus I don't waste time performing 1000 tests on poor 
genomes. 
> An alternative would be to keep testing until the first failed 
test, but 
> I don;t think this is as good since the proportion of tests passed 
in 
> the first 100 cases gives some idea of relative fitness between 
poor 
> genomes - which is all of the genomes at the start of evolution.
> 
> 
> 

This sounds like a good idea.  I will keep it in mind.  You know, 
ultimately what we are up against is just the fact that no sample 
can be guaranteed to perfectly represent its generating distribution.
It's likely there will always be extraordinary situations that were 
not encountered in whatever training set was experienced during 
evolution.  At the same time, that doesn't mean we can't do better, 
it just means reaching exactly 100% of all possible test cases is 
unlikely for complicated problems or domains.

ken
